review_blob:
Not always a huge coffee stout fan.  Often time it tastes like a waaaay over roasted coffee grounds, but this one smells outstanding

Color is gorgeous, but looks a little light and slick for my liking in a stout

Taste is okay, but it does not give the same impression as the nose, at least for the palate of this thing.  I wanted it to be more, as I loved the smell.  




---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an inky black with a tasty-looking ring of rich creamy brown head - seriously looks like the top of an espresso

Oh and smells of delicious coffee as well.  I'm not the biggest fan of coffee, but can appreciate the nose.  Hints of semi-sweet chocolate as well, but mostly the bitter coffee aroma

You understand the aroma better after you take a taste.  Holy roasted coffee beans....  It's an amazing follow-through and finish on this beer, but up front it's too heavy on the burnt coffee bean flavor, IMO.

Really really interesting and bold flavor profile.  If you like a deep roasted coffee and/or coffee stouts (ie, border-line burnt), you'll love this.    

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Terrapin Wake-n-Bake Coffee Oatmeal Imperial Stout

review_blob:
Pours a clear, bright amber.  Light layer of head, some lace on edges

Nose is citrus with just the faintest hint of booze, but in a sweet/fruity way, not hot...but more like a BW.. exactly what you'd expect an IPA with a bit of malt and high ABV to smell like

Taste is massive hop citrus, and nice dose of malt sweetness, and bitter edge to it. Sweet-ish hop bomb up front, then you get the citrus, then chewy malt, with a nice dry follow through.  Pleasant mouthfeel.  Enjoyable brew for sure.  Really enjoyed the balance and when in the mood for hops, would not hesitate to order 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a rich dark brown with full creamy foamy head

Nose is roasted dark chocolate, just a hint of smokey malt

Wow what a unique taste combo.  Tingly hops with a touch of smoke and a big bold chocolate/coffee flavor.  Roasty and rich like a nice porter, but a lighter mouth feel.  Almost could use a tiny bit more smoke, but this is one of the most thirst quenching smoked beers I've ever tasted

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brown gorgeous color, hint of dark birch beer red.  Gradually fades to light ring of froth, with lace around the mug

Smells a roasty malt, tiny bit of chocolate, tiny bit of fruit in there as well...but mostly full on malt

Don't have a ton to compare in this style, but this is tasty.  Lotta malt but still goes down very smooth.  Mouthfeel is fantastic, but almost too much on the malt....BUT if I'm going to have a beer with a bit hit of malt, this is what I want it to taste like


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob:
Nose: Nice spice, tiny bit of pear.  Peppery and dry.  Refreshing

Huge head.  Gorgeous snowy white that holds. Once settle, nice lace with a bit of snow that concentrates in middle

Beautiful spiced dryness to the flavor.  Similar to sofie from GI in that sense.  Still refreshing.  As it warms it is better maintained than sofie, but sofie has more upfront.  Need to do side by side.

Nice brew, def need to have again in summer


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a pretty, dark, coca-cola like brown color.  But the head...oh the head.  It foams into two fingers of creamy burnt orange.  It's unlike any beer I've seen I would say?

Don't love the smell of this, but my mind changes all the time on barelywines.  Dominated by sweet malt, hops barely in the background with such a domination by the maltiness, and an almost burnt TOFFEE taste.  Not that you taste smoke or burning, and not that its bad, but it's that powerful

This thing is great, but it's a lot of flavor.  Honestly when I first had it, I couldn't handle the heavy sweet malt combined with the dry hop.  But glad I waited to review as I've come around - this thing is really interesting.  Sweet toffee, a dry hops, and a heavy malt dominate the flavor.  The hoppiness has a quality that's almost like liquorice.  It's such a unique flavor I'm almost at a loss for words 

I have to be in the right mood, clearly, but this is a big time beer.  Troegs is the shit and have changed my opinion beer yet again


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a pretty reddish gold.  Think trad Belgian with a nice reddish hue

Smells sweet, but not over powering.  Like Belgian yeast with a touch of guava.  Nice

Taste is sweet and not particularly overwhelming, but it's not overly quaffable?  I like it, but it's a lot....  It's not a ton of fruit sweetness nor is it a ton of that outstanding candy sugar sweetness of the sweeter Belgians, but I think the duo makes for a palate that's a little much.  It lacks complexity and it's a mash of a few things.  

I love the effort, enjoy guava, seriously dig the idea of using what you have in your given brewing locale, and still freaking love CCB...but I'd prob not order this again




---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Cigar City Guava Grove Farmhouse Ale

review_blob:
11/4
Celebrating a ravens victory
Pours a light gold.  Looks like a wit with a bit thicker head.  Settles quickly

Nose is wheat with hint of spice.  Spiced wit with a touch of citrus hops
You can see how this could be good, but taste doesn't quite cut it... 

Decent spice/carbonation combo in mouthfeel, but still doesn't quite too it. A bit watered down.  I would definitely revisit fresh and in warmer months as it could go a long way...



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11/1/12
Nose is faint wheat and a faint light sour.  Pleasant, but not much do it and perhaps a trace of smoke although if I wasn't told the style I may not have even caught it. 

Pours a dark hazy orange with light film and bits of lace. Appearance is more like a iambic than a wheat beer.  I know it adheres to purity law - assume this is what all looked like?

Taste is light smoke and nice tart wheat.  This is a really tasty beer, but the flavor comes and goes.  I will say a lot of smoke beers almost linger too long.  This leaves ya with a tiny bit of smoke...

Can't believe I let this sit in fridge since the summer months.  This would be freaking awesome with a non-greasy grilled dish.  Grilled Gouda burger during the summer? Call me the match maker




---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: rich gold with light lacey head, predominantly on edges

Nose: Candy sugar, light fruit, touch of brett sour

Taste: nothing terribly distinguishable? It's a slightly stronger ABV, and almost seems like a Belgian strong pale ale with a bit of Brett sloppily tossed in.  Not much in follow-through

It's tasty at first but becomes a chore to take down after awhile

  





---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Sierra Nevada / Russian River BRUX Domesticated Wild Ale

review_blob:
Pours a oaky dark brown, nice and clear.  

Malty caramel.  Isn't too much more complicated than that!  

Chewy malt and caramel in this fairly tasty fall lager.  

I guess this beer is awesome for what it is, but it's a ton of malt.  Not that I'm a master brew, but considering I know what melt feels/smells/tastes like in raw form, I feel like I'm drinking a cup of liquid malt...  Now that doesn't take away from it, as it's tasty, VERY drinkable and hits the spot when ya want a tasty marzen, but perhaps this just isn't my favorite style



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

10/9/12

Have had in possession for a few months.  It's time.  Removed the cork which gave a fantastic pop.  Poured aggressively which produced a soapy, carbonated head the likes of which I haven't seen in awhile.   The bright white, wet, champagne head settled to a light coat, with minimal lace.  Color is slightly cloudy / light orange.  A shade lighter would be nice.

Nose is sour punch, a touch of orange, and some must & earth. 

The first thing that hits me is the bright mouthfeel with some light sour funk and pleasant citrus.  The follow through in taste is a bit lacking, but it's not bad.  A nice dry, fruity, champagne like after-taste that doesn't linger.  The lingering is often what I like about this style, and I don't get it here.  I'm not sure if it's sugar or yeast, but I feel like my teeth are coated.

If there are "big" beers, then this is a "small" gueuze. But that isn't a bad thing per se.  I like this and it improved with each sip



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

10/1/2012

Had this few times now, but first time rating.

A touch lighter hue than I like in quads, but a rich amber nonetheless.  Decent  foamy head that lasts. 

Nose is fig and candied brown sugar.  Touch of spice, touch of booze

Taste is a refined hit of spice and dark fruit with an ample dose of sweetness.  Creamy mouthfeel with just a bit of the bready malt that I love.  Perhaps the sweetness is a bit forced for this style (although I still enjoy it). It doesn't feel as full, complex, big, or "bready" as other quads.  But I LOVE this style at the moment so I'm being hyper critical.  I'd buy this again -  it's very nicely done being such an affordable quad brewed in the US 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - The Sixth Glass Quadrupel

review_blob: UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012

9/16/12
I've been trying to save this one, but I can't wait til Xmas....apparently the 09 batch is fantastic so it's aged enough!

Bottle was a gusher.  First ive had like this, really.  Poured into Duvel tulip.  Thick (as expected) head with nice tan color, and the beer is as dark brown as can be without being black.  Love the look

Smell is cherry and Brett.  Not expected but getting excited.  Notes of bready malt underneath.  I poured a bit cold so more fragrance likely to come

Taste: solid.  It's light sour cherries and dark fruit on top, and the amazing taste of chocolate and toffee underneath, with notes of the bready malt somewhere in there as well.  Sour on the lips and chocolate in the aftertaste 

This is super interesting beer unlike anything I've had.  I love belgian strongs and all the taste that comes with it, and i love wild ales.  What an interesting blend of the two

 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

9/15/12
Poured after long day outside.  Eating and drinking earlier...so not best palate

Dark brown, cloudy.  foamy head of dark cream that takes awhile to settle.  Like the look 

Not too much on nose, but malt, rye, and candied sugar come through.

First time in this style, but I dig it!  Low-ish alcohol and not sure what I was expecting, but this is not a 'big' beer, but it really doesn't need to be.  Tiny bit sour, tiny bit dry- not as much sweetness as on nose.    Rye bitterness is there but it's pleasant.  Though aftertaste perhaps a touch too dry and bitter

Never been a fan of brown ales, and this is certainly very different.  Don't need more than one, but it's tasty.  Would have again.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012

9/13/12.  Picked up 4-pack at pinehurst wine shoppe.  First beer of session.

Nose is incredible.  Delicate sweetness, with lemon, honey, pepper, and a touch of coriander.  Fresh.  The sort of nose that I think is outstanding year round.  This is first time I've had it so will report back this winter

This beer rocks.  The spice, citrus, vanilla, and honey hits ya all at once, and the combination makes for one refreshing sensation.   When I swallow I get a hint of peppermint and outright pepper as well.   The mouthfeel is smooth and fuller than I'd expect.  And in the aftertaste the citrus comes back, but it's way more dry.

A solid and unique beer through and through


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice pour, with the rich golden look having a nice fizz to it.  Quickly dissipates to a film.  A really pleasant smell, perhaps the spice brings out the honey?  A rich sweet smell that isn't forced.  

Taste: Up front you get honey and spice, but there's little follow-through.  I almost think the cayenne accentuates the spice, but then kills it in the aftertaste.  Perhaps it does something to the taste buds?  It's a powerful spice in an otherwise delicate flavor profile.  Still though, I'm being harsh as it's pretty damn tasty. Some reviewers say it's watery?  Disagree, and still can't believe it's 9%.  It's a tad pricey, but I'd have it again 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012

7/31/12:  At Maxs on tap first day they got in some GI.   Amazing mouthfeel, but I feel like the sugar or whatever is added dominates.  It's tasty for sure, but I almost feel the sugar coats my mouth like a glazed donut.  It's a little much

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

7/20/12: one of my favorite IPAs for a long time, but just now reviewing... Pours a dark gold with just a slight haze.  Half a finger of tan foamy head that quickly fades.  Nose is of sweet malt and bright hops, but to me the malt hits ya first.  Taste follows the aroma quite closely, and boy is it refreshing.  You definitely feel the malty burn, and the hops don't hit you that hard, so I can't see not everyone loving the balance, but it will always be refreshing!  Sweet aftertaste with a a nice dryness and it's only the dryness that lingers.  I tend to like a bit more of the hops to linger...  It's a really nice beer though, and will always be a staple because of different is.  I am always down for a sixer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance is beautiful bright gold, with a slight haze. On the nose is tasty malt and refreshing piney hops.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

7/12/12 Poured into tulip immediately after work. Pours a cloudy gold with excellent thick head which slowly settles to a finger, and nice lacing. Spicey, refreshing hops on the nose. Taste is beautifully refreshing hoppiness but with less of the spice I was expecting in the taste. The finish is dry and refreshing, but again, there isnt any of the funk or the zing I was expecting? Its a very tasty beer, but leaves a little to be desired, particularly in this style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale

review_blob:
6/11/12
Served out of a can while watching the UEFA Euros tournament, poured into my Chimay goblet.  Thin head which quickly dissipates into light film - does not seem highly carbonated.  Color is slightly cloudy amber brown.  Smell is crystal-sweet with only hints of the malty dough smell I was expecting.  Taste is pleasant (without a doubt the tastiest canned beer I've had).  First thing I noticed was the light mouthfeel and sweetness of the beer, which I wasn't expecting...and while this isn't a bad thing, it felt like the beer didn't have a lot of size to it.  However, as I let it sit, I could taste the malty chewiness through the sugars, and it was delightful.  Hints of caramel.  And while I'm emphasizing how sweet the beer is, it's not overbearing.  It's actually pretty damn good.  Will have again, and would be nice with food.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

7/9/12: pours an orangey gold, slightly hazy with appearance of high carbonation.  Foamy head and nice lacing around the glass that holds (though too cold at first).  Not much on the nose - refreshing funk with a touch of lemon grass and perhaps a touch of wheat and sugar.  Taste: sourness off the bat.  Really nice tart profile but not a lot that follows it?  Again, perhaps too cold at first.  The tartness of a lambic but no body or follow-through, and the refreshing scents of a farmhouse saison.  A small dose of dryness after the swallow

I really appreciate this beer. Its super refreshing (especially if you dig sourness), but it could have a bit more character. if Im in the mood for a refreshing tart summer funk, I will revisit.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
